rows: Denying problems; presenting overly favorable self-image. Common in custody evaluations, employment screening.
Low L, Low K, High F
Overreporting symptoms; may indicate malingering, cry for help, or genuine severe distress.
Inconsistent responding suggesting carelessness, confusion, or inability to read items.
Yea-saying response pattern; endorsing items indiscriminately.
questions.correct_value: High L, High K, Low F
options: Low L, Low K, High F
High L, High K, Low F
Elevated F, Elevated VRIN
Elevated F, Elevated TRIN (True)
questions.explanation: The 'Faking Good / Defensive' pattern on the MMPI is characterized by High L (Lie), High K (Correction/Defensiveness), and Low F (Infrequency), reflecting an attempt to deny problems and present an overly favorable self-image. This is the mirror opposite of the 'Faking Bad' pattern (Low L, Low K, High F), which is a common point of confusion on the EPPP.

questions.section: Pattern of Strengths and Weaknesses (PSW) Model
rows: Wait to fail; not empirically validated; disadvantages lower-IQ students
Theoretically grounded; identifies specific processing deficits
Complex; requires comprehensive testing; limited consensus on operationalization
questions.correct_value: Does not identify cognitive basis; no consensus on "adequate response"
options: Wait to fail; not empirically validated; disadvantages lower-IQ students
Does not identify cognitive basis; no consensus on "adequate response"
Complex; requires comprehensive testing; limited consensus on operationalization
Relies on subjective teacher judgment; lacks standardized cut-off scores
questions.explanation: The RTI (Response to Intervention) model focuses on how students respond to evidence-based interventions across tiers but is limited because it does not identify the underlying cognitive processing deficits contributing to learning difficulties, and there is no consensus on what constitutes an 'adequate response' to intervention. This distinguishes it from the Ability-Achievement Discrepancy model (criticized for 'wait to fail') and the PSW model (criticized for complexity and limited operationalization consensus).

questions.correct_value: High (~90%)
options: Moderate (~50%)
High (~90%)
Adequate (~75%)
questions.explanation: The MoCA (Montreal Cognitive Assessment) has a high sensitivity of approximately 90% for detecting Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), which is one of its key advantages over the MMSE. The MMSE, by contrast, has low MCI sensitivity (~18%), making it more likely to miss early cognitive decline. This stark difference is a commonly tested distinction on the EPPP.

rows: Depression with anxiety; guilt, self-blame, rumination; good prognosis for therapy due to high subjective distress
Antisocial behavior, impulsivity, grandiosity, substance abuse risk; poor therapy prognosis; acting out
Paranoid thinking, unusual experiences, social withdrawal, suspiciousness; associated with paranoid schizophrenia
Depression with antisocial features; substance abuse common; may present after legal consequences
Somatic preoccupation with depression; chronic pain presentation; passive, whiny
Depression with somatic features; passive, dependent, conflict-avoidant; poor insight
Hostile, blaming, passive-aggressive; interpersonal conflict; projects responsibility onto others
Severe disturbance; possible mania with psychotic features; agitation, grandiosity, disorganization
questions.correct_value: "Conversion V" -- somatic complaints with denial of psychological distress; Scale 2 lower than 1 and 3; la belle indifference; classically associated with conversion disorder
options: Depression with somatic features; passive, dependent, conflict-avoidant; poor insight
"Conversion V" -- somatic complaints with denial of psychological distress; Scale 2 lower than 1 and 3; la belle indifference; classically associated with conversion disorder
Somatic preoccupation with depression; chronic pain presentation; passive, whiny
Depression with anxiety; guilt, self-blame, rumination; good prognosis for therapy due to high subjective distress
questions.explanation: The 1-3/3-1 (Hs-Hy) code type is classically associated with the 'Conversion V' pattern, where Scales 1 (Hypochondriasis) and 3 (Hysteria) are elevated while Scale 2 (Depression) is relatively lower, creating a V-shaped profile. This pattern reflects somatic complaints with denial of psychological distress and la belle indifference, and is the MMPI profile most associated with conversion disorder. This is easily confused with the 1-2/2-1 and 2-3/3-2 code types, which also involve somatic concerns but include prominent depression.

questions.correct_value: Gsm
options: Gs
Gsm
Gf
Glr
questions.explanation: In the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) model, Working Memory corresponds to Gsm (short-term memory). This is commonly confused with Gs (processing speed) or Glr (long-term retrieval), which are other CHC broad abilities but map to different factors.

rows: Treatment plan; consider counseling and/or pharmacotherapy
Immediate initiation of pharmacotherapy; consider referral to specialist
questions.correct_value: Active treatment with pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy
options: Treatment plan; consider counseling and/or pharmacotherapy
Active treatment with pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy
Immediate initiation of pharmacotherapy; consider referral to specialist
Watchful waiting; repeat at follow-up
questions.explanation: A PHQ-9 score of 15-19 indicates 'Moderately Severe' depression, which calls for active treatment with pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy. This is distinguished from the 'Moderate' range (10-14), which suggests considering counseling/pharmacotherapy, and the 'Severe' range (20-27), which calls for immediate pharmacotherapy initiation and possible specialist referral.

rows: Facilitating mourning, reconnecting with social supports
Conflicts with significant other about expectations
Mourning the old role, embracing the new role, developing supports
Chronic social isolation or poor social skills
Building social skills, expanding social network
questions.correct_value: Identifying the dispute, clarifying expectations, negotiation
options: Building social skills, expanding social network
Identifying the dispute, clarifying expectations, negotiation
Facilitating mourning, reconnecting with social supports
Mourning the old role, embracing the new role, developing supports
questions.explanation: In IPT, Role Disputes involve conflicts with a significant other about expectations. The treatment focus is on identifying the dispute, clarifying expectations, and negotiation â€” distinguishing it from Role Transitions (which focuses on mourning the old role and embracing the new one) or Interpersonal Deficits (which focuses on building social skills).

questions.correct_value: Near zero or negative
options: Moderate to strong positive
Low to moderate
Near zero or negative
Strong negative only
questions.explanation: In Holland's hexagonal model, opposite types (e.g., Realistic-Social) are positioned across from each other on the hexagon, meaning they share the least similarity. According to the calculus hypothesis, the expected correlation between opposite types is near zero or negative, reflecting their conceptual and empirical dissimilarity.

rows: Alliance, empathy, goal consensus/collaboration, positive regard/affirmation, congruence/genuineness
questions.correct_value: Collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, promoting treatment credibility
options: Self-disclosure, immediacy, emotional expression
Alliance, empathy, goal consensus/collaboration, positive regard/affirmation, congruence/genuineness
Collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, promoting treatment credibility
Empathy, collecting client feedback, immediacy, repairing alliance ruptures
questions.explanation: According to Norcross's evidence-based relationship elements, the 'Probably Effective' category includes collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, and promoting treatment credibility. These are distinguished from 'Demonstrably Effective' elements (e.g., alliance, empathy) which have stronger empirical support, and 'Promising' elements (e.g., self-disclosure, immediacy) which have emerging but less established evidence.

questions.section: Disadvantages of Structured and Semi-Structured Interviews
rows: Gold standard for research; DSM-5 modules
Brief; good sensitivity; primary care use
No clinical training needed; epidemiological use
questions.correct_value: Interviews child AND parent; present & lifetime
options: Brief; good sensitivity; primary care use
No clinical training needed; epidemiological use
Gold standard for research; DSM-5 modules
Interviews child AND parent; present & lifetime
questions.explanation: The K-SADS (Kiddie Schedule for Affective Disorders and Schizophrenia) is distinctive because it requires interviewing both the child AND the parent, and it assesses both present and lifetime diagnoses. This differentiates it from the DISC, which is also used with children/adolescents but is fully structured and designed for lay interviewers in epidemiological research.

rows: Items rarely endorsed by the normative sample; elevated scores suggest overreporting, random responding, or genuine severe pathology
Infrequent responses to items in the latter half of the test; detects declining effort or shift in response style
Originally developed for personal injury malingering; detects somatic and cognitive symptom overreporting in litigation contexts
Identifies overreporting of memory complaints specifically; useful in neuropsychological contexts
questions.correct_value: Items rarely endorsed even by genuine psychiatric patients; elevated Fp is the strongest single MMPI indicator of malingering because it differentiates faking from genuine severe pathology
options: Items rarely endorsed by the normative sample; elevated scores suggest overreporting, random responding, or genuine severe pathology
Items rarely endorsed even by genuine psychiatric patients; elevated Fp is the strongest single MMPI indicator of malingering because it differentiates faking from genuine severe pathology
Originally developed for personal injury malingering; detects somatic and cognitive symptom overreporting in litigation contexts
Identifies overreporting of memory complaints specifically; useful in neuropsychological contexts
questions.explanation: The Fp (Infrequent Psychopathology) scale is uniquely important because it contains items rarely endorsed even by genuine psychiatric patients. This makes it the strongest single MMPI indicator of malingering, as an elevated F scale alone could reflect genuine severe pathology, whereas elevated Fp specifically differentiates faking from true psychopathology.

rows: Identify target memories, current triggers, and future desired behaviors
Establish therapeutic relationship; teach self-regulation skills (safe place imagery)
Bilateral stimulation while focusing on the target memory; continue until SUDS = 0
Strengthen the positive cognition (VOC = 7); pair it with the target memory
Identify and process any residual somatic disturbance
Return client to equilibrium; use self-regulation strategies if needed
Check treatment effects at next session; identify new targets if needed
questions.correct_value: Activate target memory; identify image, negative cognition, positive cognition, VOC, emotions, SUDS, body location
options: Bilateral stimulation while focusing on the target memory; continue until SUDS = 0
Activate target memory; identify image, negative cognition, positive cognition, VOC, emotions, SUDS, body location
Identify target memories, current triggers, and future desired behaviors
Strengthen the positive cognition (VOC = 7); pair it with the target memory
questions.explanation: Phase 3 (Assessment) in EMDR involves activating the target memory and identifying its key components: the representative image, negative cognition, desired positive cognition, Validity of Cognition (VOC) rating, emotions, Subjective Units of Disturbance Scale (SUDS) rating, and body location of disturbance. This is commonly confused with Phase 4 (Desensitization), which involves bilateral stimulation, or Phase 5 (Installation), which focuses on strengthening the positive cognition.

questions.section: Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children - Fifth Edition (WISC-V)
questions.correct_value: Digit Span, Picture Span
options: Digit Span, Letter-Number Sequencing
Digit Span, Coding
Digit Span, Picture Span
Digit Span, Arithmetic
questions.explanation: The WISC-V Working Memory Index (WMI) uses Digit Span and Picture Span as its core subtests. Picture Span is a new addition in the WISC-V, replacing Letter-Number Sequencing (which was a core WMI subtest on the WISC-IV). Arithmetic is a supplemental subtest for WMI on the WISC-V, not a core subtest.

rows: Cognitive Therapy (Beck), Behavioral Activation, Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
CBT (including applied relaxation), Acceptance-based behavioral therapy
CBT (Barlow's Panic Control Treatment), exposure-based therapies
CBT (cognitive restructuring + exposure), Social Effectiveness Therapy
Exposure therapy (in vivo, systematic desensitization), applied tension (blood-injection-injury)
Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), CBT with ERP
Prolonged Exposure (Foa), Cognitive Processing Therapy (Resick), EMDR
Family-Based Treatment (Maudsley), no individual therapy has strong support as standalone
Motivational Interviewing / MET, CBT (Relapse Prevention), Contingency Management, 12-Step Facilitation
CBT for Insomnia (CBT-I), stimulus control, sleep restriction
Social Skills Training, CBT for psychosis, Family Psychoeducation, supported employment
Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT), Parent Management Training (PMT, Kazdin)
Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA), Early Intensive Behavioral Intervention
questions.correct_value: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (Linehan), Mentalization-Based Therapy, Transference-Focused Psychotherapy
options: CBT (cognitive restructuring + exposure), Schema Therapy, Interpersonal Therapy
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (Linehan), Mentalization-Based Therapy, Transference-Focused Psychotherapy
Prolonged Exposure (Foa), Cognitive Processing Therapy (Resick), EMDR
Motivational Interviewing / MET, CBT (Relapse Prevention), Contingency Management, 12-Step Facilitation
questions.explanation: The well-established ESTs for Borderline Personality Disorder are Dialectical Behavior Therapy (developed by Linehan), Mentalization-Based Therapy, and Transference-Focused Psychotherapy. These three modalities have the strongest empirical support for BPD. DBT is the most widely recognized, but MBT and TFP also meet criteria for well-established treatments. Schema Therapy, while sometimes used, is not typically grouped with these three as a well-established EST for BPD on the EPPP.

rows: Crystallized intelligence (Gc): verbal reasoning, word knowledge, acquired information
Fluid reasoning (Gf) and visual-spatial processing (Gv): nonverbal reasoning, spatial analysis
Short-term memory (Gsm): mental manipulation, attention, concentration
Processing speed (Gs): speed of visual scanning, motor output, and mental processing
questions.correct_value: Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, Visual Puzzles
options: Digit Span, Arithmetic
Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, Visual Puzzles
Similarities, Vocabulary, Information
Symbol Search, Coding
questions.explanation: The Perceptual Reasoning Index (PRI) on the WAIS-IV uses Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, and Visual Puzzles as its core subtests. These subtests measure fluid reasoning (Gf) and visual-spatial processing (Gv), requiring nonverbal reasoning and spatial analysis. A common error is confusing these with the core subtests of other indices, such as Working Memory (Digit Span, Arithmetic) or Verbal Comprehension (Similarities, Vocabulary, Information).

rows: Full opioid agonist; prevents withdrawal, reduces craving
Aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor; causes nausea if alcohol consumed
questions.correct_value: NMDA/GABA modulation; reduces craving in abstinent patients
options: Aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor; causes nausea if alcohol consumed
Opioid antagonist; blocks euphoric effects
NMDA/GABA modulation; reduces craving in abstinent patients
Partial opioid agonist; reduces cravings/withdrawal
questions.explanation: Acamprosate works through NMDA and GABA modulation to reduce cravings specifically in patients who have already achieved abstinence from alcohol. This is distinct from disulfiram, which uses aversive conditioning via aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibition, and from naltrexone, which is an opioid antagonist that blocks euphoric effects. Acamprosate's unique mechanism and its specific role in maintaining (rather than initiating) abstinence make it a commonly tested medication on the EPPP.

rows: Teaches the four skills modules; structured psychoeducational format; NOT process-oriented group therapy
Helps generalize skills to everyday life; brief coaching during crises; NOT therapy between sessions
Supports therapist motivation and competence; prevents burnout; "therapy for the therapist"
questions.correct_value: Addresses treatment targets using hierarchy: life-threatening behaviors > therapy-interfering behaviors > quality-of-life-interfering behaviors > skills acquisition
options: Teaches the four skills modules; structured psychoeducational format; NOT process-oriented group therapy
Addresses treatment targets using hierarchy: life-threatening behaviors > therapy-interfering behaviors > quality-of-life-interfering behaviors > skills acquisition
Addresses treatment targets using hierarchy: therapy-interfering behaviors > life-threatening behaviors > quality-of-life-interfering behaviors > skills acquisition
Helps generalize skills to everyday life; brief coaching during crises; NOT therapy between sessions
questions.explanation: In DBT individual therapy, the treatment target hierarchy places life-threatening behaviors first, followed by therapy-interfering behaviors, then quality-of-life-interfering behaviors, and finally skills acquisition. A common EPPP error is reversing the order of life-threatening and therapy-interfering behaviors, but life-threatening behaviors always take top priority in the DBT hierarchy.

Wechsler subtest scaled scores have a mean of 10 and a standard deviation of 3. This is commonly confused with the SD of stanines (~2), z-scores (1), or T-scores (10), but the SD of 3 is specific to Wechsler subtest scaled scores.

rows: Depression with interpersonal issues; postpartum depression
Dialectical balance of acceptance and change
questions.correct_value: Relapse prevention (3+ episodes)
options: Acute major depression
Relapse prevention (3+ episodes)
Depression with interpersonal issues; postpartum depression
Acute depression (including severe)
questions.explanation: MBCT (Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy) was specifically developed and validated for relapse prevention in patients with 3 or more prior depressive episodes. It is not primarily indicated for acute depression treatment, which distinguishes it from CBT, Behavioral Activation, and IPT.

rows: Emotional instability, proneness to negative affect, vulnerability to stress
Warmth, Gregariousness, Assertiveness, Activity, Excitement-Seeking, Positive Emotions
Intellectual curiosity, imagination, aesthetic sensitivity, openness to new experiences
Fantasy, Aesthetics, Feelings, Actions, Ideas, Values
Trust, Straightforwardness, Altruism, Compliance, Modesty, Tender-Mindedness
Competence, Order, Dutifulness, Achievement Striving, Self-Discipline, Deliberation
questions.correct_value: Anxiety, Angry Hostility, Depression, Self-Consciousness, Impulsiveness, Vulnerability
options: Trust, Straightforwardness, Altruism, Compliance, Modesty, Tender-Mindedness
Anxiety, Angry Hostility, Depression, Self-Consciousness, Impulsiveness, Vulnerability
Fantasy, Aesthetics, Feelings, Actions, Ideas, Values
Warmth, Gregariousness, Assertiveness, Activity, Excitement-Seeking, Positive Emotions
questions.explanation: The six facets of Neuroticism on the NEO-PI-R are Anxiety, Angry Hostility, Depression, Self-Consciousness, Impulsiveness, and Vulnerability. These facets all reflect aspects of emotional instability and proneness to negative affect, which define the Neuroticism domain. A common error is confusing Impulsiveness (a Neuroticism facet) with Excitement-Seeking (an Extraversion facet).

rows: Single factor; more restrictive for novel science
questions.correct_value: Testability, peer review, error rate, general acceptance
options: General acceptance only
Testability, peer review, error rate, general acceptance
Peer review, reliability, relevance, probative value
Testability, falsifiability, peer review, judicial notice
questions.explanation: Under Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals (1993), the U.S. Supreme Court established a multi-factor test for the admissibility of expert testimony in federal courts. The four criteria the trial judge considers are: (1) testability/falsifiability, (2) peer review and publication, (3) known or potential error rate, and (4) general acceptance within the relevant scientific community. This replaced the single 'general acceptance' standard from Frye v. United States (1923).

questions.section: Summary Table: Anxiety Disorder Treatments by Diagnosis
rows: Graduated or intensive exposure; applied tension for BII
Behavioral experiments, video feedback, reducing safety behaviors
Interoceptive exposure, cognitive restructuring of catastrophic misinterpretations
Graduated approach to avoided situations; address safety behaviors
Worry exposure, cognitive restructuring, intolerance of uncertainty, relaxation
Exposure to obsessional triggers + prevention of compulsive rituals
Imaginal + in vivo exposure; cognitive processing; bilateral stimulation
PRACTICE components; includes caregiver sessions and trauma narrative
questions.correct_value: PE / CPT / EMDR
options: ERP / CBT / EMDR
TF-CBT / CPT / DBT
PE / CPT / EMDR
CBT / PE / Applied relaxation
questions.explanation: The three first-line psychotherapies for adult PTSD are Prolonged Exposure (PE), Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR). These are the treatments with the strongest empirical support for adult PTSD, each targeting trauma processing through different mechanisms: imaginal and in vivo exposure (PE), cognitive restructuring of trauma-related beliefs (CPT), and bilateral stimulation during trauma recall (EMDR).

rows: Intensive, personalized, safe for personal exploration
Less individual attention, potential for conformity pressure
Blends individual and group benefits, moderately efficient
Requires balancing attention between two supervisees
questions.correct_value: No formal authority, does not count toward licensure
options: Less individual attention, potential for conformity pressure
No formal authority, does not count toward licensure
May be intrusive, logistically complex
Requires balancing attention between two supervisees
questions.explanation: Peer supervision is conducted among colleagues without a hierarchical supervisory relationship, meaning there is no formal evaluative authority. Critically for licensure candidates, peer supervision typically does not count toward the supervised hours required for licensure, distinguishing it from other supervision formats that involve a designated, credentialed supervisor.

rows: Coping skills, cognitive restructuring, AVE prevention
questions.correct_value: Alcohol
options: Cocaine, methamphetamine, opioids
Alcohol, mixed substance use
Alcohol
Cocaine
questions.explanation: Twelve-Step Facilitation (TSF) has its strongest evidence base specifically for alcohol use disorders, based on landmark studies such as Project MATCH. This distinguishes it from other approaches like CM (strongest for stimulants/opioids) or MI/MET (which has broader evidence for alcohol and mixed substance use).

rows: Emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, reduced accomplishment from chronic workplace stress
Develops gradually; related to organizational factors
Emotional toll from working with traumatized clients
Can develop rapidly; related to trauma exposure
Changes in therapist's cognitive schemas from empathic engagement with trauma
Therapist's emotional reactions to the client
Specific to individual client; can be informative if managed
Decline in functioning that compromises client care
Triggers ethical and legal obligations; may require reporting
questions.correct_value: Cumulative; affects worldview (safety, trust, control)
options: Can develop rapidly; related to trauma exposure
Cumulative; affects worldview (safety, trust, control)
Develops gradually; related to organizational factors
Specific to individual client; can be informative if managed
questions.explanation: Vicarious traumatization is distinguished from related concepts by its cumulative nature and its specific impact on the therapist's cognitive schemasâ€”particularly beliefs about safety, trust, and control. This differs from compassion fatigue (which can develop rapidly), burnout (which is tied to organizational/workplace factors), and countertransference (which is specific to reactions toward an individual client).

rows: Completely nonverbal administration and response; no spoken language required
Uses gestures for instruction; six subtests measuring memory and reasoning
Abstract/figural problem-solving; pointing response only; brief screening measure
questions.correct_value: Pattern completion; best single measure of g; minimal verbal demands
options: Abstract/figural problem-solving; pointing response only; brief screening measure
Pattern completion; best single measure of g; minimal verbal demands
Completely nonverbal administration and response; no spoken language required
Uses gestures for instruction; six subtests measuring memory and reasoning
questions.explanation: Raven's Progressive Matrices is widely recognized as the best single measure of Spearman's g (general intelligence). It uses pattern completion tasks with minimal verbal demands, distinguishing it from other nonverbal tests like the TONI-4 (which focuses on abstract/figural problem-solving as a brief screening measure) or the Leiter-3 (which is completely nonverbal in both administration and response).

rows: 9-16 designs to copy; screening tool; Koppitz scoring for children
30-point scale; cutoff 23/24; limited executive function assessment
Card sorting by color/form/number; perseverative errors key score
A = sequencing; B = alternating sets; B-A discrepancy = executive dysfunction
Fixed battery; Impairment Index; 4 interpretive methods
11 clinical scales; based on Luria; shorter than HRB
Copy + recall; 18 elements; organizational strategy important
questions.correct_value: 30-point scale; cutoff 26; better for MCI detection; includes executive tasks
options: 30-point scale; cutoff 23/24; limited executive function assessment
30-point scale; cutoff 26; better for MCI detection; includes executive tasks
30-point scale; cutoff 28; better for dementia detection; includes memory tasks
30-point scale; cutoff 24; screens for delirium; includes attention tasks
questions.explanation: The MoCA (Montreal Cognitive Assessment) uses a 30-point scale with a cutoff of 26 (compared to the MMSE's cutoff of 23/24) and is specifically noted for being better at detecting Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) because it includes executive function tasks that the MMSE lacks. This is a highly testable distinction because the MMSE and MoCA are frequently confused due to their shared 30-point scale, but they differ critically in their cutoff scores and sensitivity to MCI.

rows: A non-dangerous, mentally ill person who can survive safely in freedom cannot be involuntarily confined. Mental illness alone is insufficient.
Established the right to treatment in the least restrictive environment for involuntarily committed individuals.
Involuntarily committed individuals have constitutional rights to safety, freedom from unnecessary restraint, and minimally adequate training/habilitation.
questions.correct_value: The standard of proof for civil commitment must be at least "clear and convincing evidence" â€” higher than civil "preponderance of evidence" but lower than criminal "beyond a reasonable doubt."
options: Established the right to treatment in the least restrictive environment for involuntarily committed individuals.
The standard of proof for civil commitment must be at least "clear and convincing evidence" â€” higher than civil "preponderance of evidence" but lower than criminal "beyond a reasonable doubt."
A non-dangerous, mentally ill person who can survive safely in freedom cannot be involuntarily confined. Mental illness alone is insufficient.
Involuntarily committed individuals have constitutional rights to safety, freedom from unnecessary restraint, and minimally adequate training/habilitation.
questions.explanation: Addington v. Texas (1979) is the landmark case that established 'clear and convincing evidence' as the minimum standard of proof required for civil commitment proceedings. This is a frequently tested distinction on the EPPP because it falls between the lower civil standard ('preponderance of evidence') and the higher criminal standard ('beyond a reasonable doubt').

rows: Did not know the nature and quality of the act OR did not know the act was wrong (cognitive test only)
The act was the product of mental disease or defect (broadest standard; largely abandoned)
Lacked substantial capacity to appreciate wrongfulness OR to conform conduct to the law (includes volitional prong)
questions.correct_value: Severe mental disease/defect; unable to appreciate wrongfulness (federal standard; eliminated volitional prong after Hinckley)
options: Lacked substantial capacity to appreciate wrongfulness OR to conform conduct to the law (includes volitional prong)
Did not know the nature and quality of the act OR did not know the act was wrong (cognitive test only)
Severe mental disease/defect; unable to appreciate wrongfulness (federal standard; eliminated volitional prong after Hinckley)
The act was the product of mental disease or defect (broadest standard; largely abandoned)
questions.explanation: The Insanity Defense Reform Act (IDRA) of 1984 was enacted in response to John Hinckley Jr.'s acquittal. It narrowed the federal insanity standard by requiring a 'severe' mental disease or defect, retaining only the cognitive prong (unable to appreciate wrongfulness), and critically eliminating the volitional prong ('conform conduct to the law') that had been part of the ALI/Model Penal Code standard.

questions.correct_value: NMDA partial agonist; enhances extinction learning
options: 5-HT1A partial agonist; no sedation/dependence
NMDA partial agonist; enhances extinction learning
Enhance GABA-A activity
Block peripheral sympathetic symptoms
questions.explanation: D-cycloserine (DCS) acts as a partial agonist at the NMDA receptor, which plays a critical role in learning and memory. When used as an augmentation strategy alongside exposure therapy, it enhances extinction learningâ€”the process by which fear associations are weakened. This mechanism is distinct from buspirone's 5-HT1A partial agonism or benzodiazepines' GABA-A enhancement.

questions.correct_value: 2nd-8th
options: 9th-24th
2nd-8th
Below 2nd
5th-15th
questions.explanation: The Borderline IQ classification (70-79) corresponds to the 2nd-8th percentile range. This is commonly confused with the Low Average range (9th-24th percentile) immediately above it and the Extremely Low range (Below 2nd percentile) immediately below it. Knowing the precise percentile cutoffs for Borderline functioning is critical for diagnostic and classification decisions on the EPPP.

The cumulative percentage from below at -1 SD is 15.87%, which is the sum of all scores below -1 SD: 0.13% (below -3 SD) + 2.14% (-3 to -2 SD) + 13.59% (-2 to -1 SD) = 15.87%. This is a critical value for the EPPP because it represents the percentage of scores falling below one standard deviation below the mean in a normal distribution.

rows: Oscillating focus between self and client
Less structure, more autonomy; process exploration
questions.correct_value: Vacillating (dependency-autonomy conflict)
options: Conditional dependency (consults when needed)
Vacillating (dependency-autonomy conflict)
Low (dependent on supervisor)
Integrated
questions.explanation: In Stoltenberg's IDM, Level 2 supervisees experience a vacillating autonomy characterized by a dependency-autonomy conflict, where they swing between wanting independence and needing supervisory guidance. This distinguishes them from Level 1 (low autonomy, dependent) and Level 3 (conditional dependency, consulting only when needed).

Stanine 6 corresponds to the percentile range of 60-76 and is described as 'High Average.' This is commonly confused with the adjacent stanine 5 (40-59, Average) and stanine 7 (77-88, Above Average). The percentile boundaries for each stanine are important to know for accurate score interpretation on the EPPP.

According to Lambert's outcome factors, common factors (i.e., the therapeutic relationship) account for an estimated 30% of the variance in therapy outcomes. This is the second largest contributor after extratherapeutic/client factors (40%), and is frequently tested because it is often confused with the 15% attributed to specific techniques or expectancy/placebo effects.

A z-score of -2.0 corresponds to an IQ score of 70, calculated as M + (z Ã— SD) = 100 + (-2.0 Ã— 15) = 70. This is a critical cutoff on the EPPP because an IQ of 70 (2 standard deviations below the mean) is the traditional threshold for an intellectual disability diagnosis.

rows: Practical, hands-on, mechanical; prefers working with things and tools
Analytical, intellectual, scientific; prefers observation and problem-solving
Creative, expressive, nonconforming; prefers unstructured activities
Helping, cooperative, interpersonal; prefers teaching and caregiving
Organized, detail-oriented, systematic; prefers structured tasks
questions.correct_value: Persuasive, competitive, leadership-oriented; prefers business activities
options: Organized, detail-oriented, systematic; prefers structured tasks
Helping, cooperative, interpersonal; prefers teaching and caregiving
Persuasive, competitive, leadership-oriented; prefers business activities
Practical, hands-on, mechanical; prefers working with things and tools
questions.explanation: The Enterprising (E) type in Holland's RIASEC model is characterized by persuasive, competitive, and leadership-oriented traits with a preference for business activities. This is frequently confused with the Social (S) type due to both involving interpersonal interaction, but Enterprising emphasizes persuasion and competition rather than helping and caregiving.

questions.correct_value: Modifying trauma-related stuck points
options: Emotional processing via exposure
Adaptive information processing
Modifying trauma-related stuck points
Graduated exposure + caregiver skills
questions.explanation: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), developed by Resick, focuses specifically on identifying and modifying 'stuck points' â€” maladaptive beliefs about the trauma related to safety, trust, power, esteem, and intimacy. This distinguishes it from Prolonged Exposure (which emphasizes emotional processing via habituation to trauma cues) and EMDR (which targets adaptive information processing through bilateral stimulation).

rows: Dual model (CHC and Luria); MPI excludes crystallized
Best single measure of g; minimal verbal demands
No verbal response required; vocabulary screening only
Group-administered; used for gifted screening and instructional planning
Cattell's culture-fair test; abstract figural items
questions.correct_value: Completely nonverbal administration and response; pantomime instructions
options: No verbal response required; vocabulary screening only
Completely nonverbal administration and response; pantomime instructions
Best single measure of g; minimal verbal demands
Cattell's culture-fair test; abstract figural items
questions.explanation: The Leiter-3 is unique among cognitive measures in that it requires absolutely no verbal communication from either the examiner or the examinee â€” instructions are given entirely through pantomime. This distinguishes it from instruments like the Raven's SPM (which has minimal verbal demands but is not completely nonverbal in administration) and the PPVT-5 (which requires no verbal response from the examinee but does involve verbal administration by the examiner).

rows: Group differences in item performance at equal trait levels
Different regression lines for different groups
Test measures different constructs across groups
questions.correct_value: Moderated regression analysis
options: Measurement invariance, factor analysis
DIF analysis (Mantel-Haenszel, IRT methods)
Moderated regression analysis
Confirmatory factor analysis with multi-group comparison
questions.explanation: Predictive bias is detected through moderated regression analysis, which examines whether the regression lines (slopes and intercepts) predicting a criterion from test scores differ across groups. If separate regression equations are needed for different groups, predictive bias is present. This is distinct from DIF analysis (used for item bias) and factor analytic methods (used for construct bias).

rows: Not considering change; unaware or in denial
Raise awareness; explore pros of status quo and cons of change
Planning to change; committed but not yet acting
Support planning; explore options; strengthen commitment
Support self-efficacy; problem-solve barriers; reinforce efforts
Prevent relapse; reinforce gains; address ongoing challenges
questions.correct_value: Explore ambivalence; develop discrepancy; elicit change talk
options: Raise awareness; explore pros of status quo and cons of change
Explore ambivalence; develop discrepancy; elicit change talk
Support self-efficacy; problem-solve barriers; reinforce efforts
Support planning; explore options; strengthen commitment
questions.explanation: In the Contemplation stage, the client is ambivalent and weighing pros and cons of change. The appropriate MI strategy is to explore that ambivalence, develop discrepancy between current behavior and goals, and elicit change talk â€” helping the client move toward a commitment to change. This is distinct from the Precontemplation strategy (raising awareness) or the Preparation strategy (supporting planning).

rows: Somatic symptoms under stress, denial, need for approval
questions.correct_value: Anxiety, obsessiveness, worry, rumination
options: Suspiciousness, sensitivity, persecutory ideation
Anxiety, obsessiveness, worry, rumination
Unusual thinking, alienation, perceptual disturbance
Elevated mood, grandiosity, overactivity, impulsivity
questions.explanation: Scale 7 (Pt/Psychasthenia) on the MMPI-2 measures anxiety, obsessiveness, worry, and rumination. This is commonly confused with Scale 8 (Sc/Schizophrenia) which involves unusual thinking and perceptual disturbance, or Scale 6 (Pa/Paranoia) which involves suspiciousness. The term 'psychasthenia' is an older term for obsessive-compulsive and anxiety-related symptoms.

rows: Number of items left unanswered. More than 30 unanswered items invalidates the profile.
Naive, unsophisticated attempts to present oneself in a favorable light. Denying common human faults. Elevated L = "faking good" or rigid/moralistic personality.
Items endorsed by fewer than 10% of the normative sample. Elevated F = "faking bad," exaggeration, random responding, severe psychopathology, or a "cry for help."
More sophisticated defensiveness than L. Moderate K = healthy self-presentation; very high K = denial/defensiveness; very low K = excessive openness or self-criticism.
Infrequency items from the second half of the test. Detects changes in response style partway through administration.
Pairs of items with similar or opposite content; inconsistent responding suggests random or careless responding.
Pairs of items where answering both True or both False is contradictory. Detects acquiescence (yea-saying) or nay-saying bias.
Items reflecting an extremely positive self-view; supplement to L and K for detecting underreporting.
questions.correct_value: Items infrequently endorsed even by psychiatric inpatients. Helps distinguish genuine severe psychopathology (F elevated, Fp normal) from overreporting (both elevated).
options: Items endorsed by fewer than 10% of the normative sample. Elevated F = "faking bad," exaggeration, random responding, severe psychopathology, or a "cry for help."
Items infrequently endorsed even by psychiatric inpatients. Helps distinguish genuine severe psychopathology (F elevated, Fp normal) from overreporting (both elevated).
Infrequency items from the second half of the test. Detects changes in response style partway through administration.
Pairs of items with similar or opposite content; inconsistent responding suggests random or careless responding.
questions.explanation: The Fp (Infrequency-Psychopathology) scale specifically uses items that are infrequently endorsed even by psychiatric inpatients, which distinguishes it from the standard F scale. This allows clinicians to differentiate genuine severe psychopathology (where F is elevated but Fp remains normal) from overreporting or malingering (where both F and Fp are elevated). This is a commonly tested distinction on the EPPP because F and Fp are easily confused.

rows: Prefers hands-on, physical, mechanical, or outdoor activities; values practical solutions
Prefers analytical, intellectual, scientific activities; values research and inquiry
Prefers creative, unstructured, expressive activities; values aesthetics and imagination
Artist, musician, writer, actor, graphic designer
Prefers helping, teaching, counseling, and cooperative activities; values interpersonal relationships
Prefers leading, persuading, managing, and selling activities; values influence and status
questions.correct_value: Prefers structured, organized, data-management activities; values accuracy and order
options: Prefers hands-on, physical, mechanical, or outdoor activities; values practical solutions
Prefers structured, organized, data-management activities; values accuracy and order
Prefers analytical, intellectual, scientific activities; values research and inquiry
Prefers leading, persuading, managing, and selling activities; values influence and status
questions.explanation: The Conventional (C) type in Holland's RIASEC model is characterized by a preference for structured, organized, data-management activities and a valuing of accuracy and order. This is commonly confused with the Investigative type (which values research and inquiry) or the Realistic type (which values practical solutions), but the Conventional type is specifically distinguished by its emphasis on orderliness, structure, and data management rather than scientific inquiry or hands-on physical work.

questions.section: Objective vs. Projective Assessment: The Debate
rows: Variable; interrater reliability can be high with standardized systems
Less transparent purpose; harder to fake
questions.correct_value: More limited; select variables well-supported
options: Extensive empirical support
More limited; select variables well-supported
Variable; interrater reliability can be high with standardized systems
Generally high (alpha > .80)
questions.explanation: Projective tests have more limited validity evidence compared to objective tests, though select variables (e.g., certain Rorschach indices scored with standardized systems like R-PAS) do have well-supported validity. This is a key distinction from objective tests, which have extensive empirical support for validity, and is frequently tested on the EPPP.

Bizarre thinking, social alienation, unusual perceptions, poor reality testing, confusion
Elevated mood, grandiosity, hyperactivity, impulsivity, flight of ideas, irritability

questions.correct_value: Anxiety, obsessive-compulsive features, guilt, self-doubt, indecisiveness, rumination
options: Suspiciousness, sensitivity, hostility, rigidity, paranoid ideation, persecutory beliefs
Anxiety, obsessive-compulsive features, guilt, self-doubt, indecisiveness, rumination
Bizarre thinking, social alienation, unusual perceptions, poor reality testing, confusion
Depressed mood, psychomotor retardation, hopelessness, social withdrawal
questions.explanation: Scale 7 (Psychasthenia, Pt) is characterized by anxiety, obsessive-compulsive features, guilt, self-doubt, indecisiveness, and rumination. This is commonly confused with Scale 2 (Depression) due to overlapping negative affect, and with Scale 6 (Paranoia) due to overlapping cognitive distortions, but Pt specifically captures the anxious, ruminative, and obsessional quality of distress.
